nodes.text: Intergenerational rank-based mobility in the United States has not declined for children born 1971–1993; recent cohorts have similar chances of moving up relative to their parents as 1970s cohorts
Rank-based measures of mobility are stable across cohorts (no trend in rank-rank slopes)
We combine population tax records (linked parent-child sample for 1980–1993 cohorts covering ~95 percent linkage) with SOI stratified cross sections for 1971–1982 cohorts

Mobility is measured using rank-rank regressions (child rank at ages 29–30 and 26), college attendance gradients (indicator for 1098-T at age 19), quintile transition matrices, and consolidated series combining these measures
For 1971–1982 cohorts (SOI sample) rank-rank slopes are ~0.30 (s.e. <0.01) and the rank-rank relationship is nearly linear
Age-26 rank-rank slopes for 1980–1986 cohorts (population sample) show no trend and are highly correlated with age-30 area estimates
College attendance gradient (gap in college rates between lowest- and highest-income parents) is essentially constant at about 74.5 percent for 1984–1989, falling slightly to 69.2 percent by 1993
Construct consolidated series by scaling age-26 income gradients (factor 1.12) and college gradients (factor 0.40) to predict age-30 rank-rank slopes for 1971–1993 cohorts
Consolidated series trend is effectively flat: estimated slope −0.0006 per birth year (23 observations), 95 percent upper bound 0.0008, implying at most 0.27 percent per year increase in persistence
Quintile transition probabilities show little change: probability of reaching top quintile from bottom was 8.4 percent in 1971 and 9.0 percent in 1986 (child income at age 26)
Parent and child marginal income distributions widened substantially over time: increases in Gini coefficients and top income shares are large
Conclusion: Rank-based intergenerational mobility remained stable, but increased inequality magnified the consequences of the birth lottery so parental background affects expected incomes more today
Regional differences in mobility are large and persistent: some areas (Southeast) have low upward mobility while others (Mountain states) have much higher mobility

Data and variable definitions: parent family income defined using adjusted gross income plus non-taxable items or W-2/1099/SSA forms for nonfilers; child income measured from population files; college attendance via 1098-T
Assumption used for forecasting: college and age-26 gradients are proportional (constant multiples) of the age-30 income gradient
